4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:54): boblet proposed using css transitions and transforms without the prefix (in addition to the prefixed variants) as the spec isnt likely to change and end users are unlikely to update their code when the spec hits CR...
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:54): i can totally see that POV but i've been holding off on going unprefixed for un-cr things so far..
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:55): anyone here take a side on that?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:55): As long as you're willing to go back and fix your code, there's no problem.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:55): yes, there is
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:55): implementors don't know if your site is maintained by a person who is willing to adjust
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:55): i can handle either case, i just want to make the right recommendation to other developers.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:55): wants to write a mixin spec for CSS which would solve the prefix problem without the problems of removing them entirely.
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:56): who are likely a lot more lazy
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:56): (I use unprefixed stuff myself, though.)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:56): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: But going with or without prefixes both cause problems for implementors.

13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512 (21:56): let's say I create an image in JS and point it to a PNG file in the server with _.src property, when does the browser actually starts to download it? also when the image.onload event occurs, does it mean that the download is finished or that the image is in the memory? or do I make any kind of sense :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:56): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: indeed, I use unprefixed versions partly in protest against long-term prefixing
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:57): webkit animation is one i'd certainly not leave unprefixed. that seems to be a bit more contentious, yes?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:57): Animation's complex enough that I wouldn't unprefix it.  Too much change of *something* changing underneath you.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:58): And yeah, the convo's died down somewhat, but I'm agitating for some changes to animations.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:58): 13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512: It could start to download in the background as soon as you set .src, though I don't know whether browsers will wait for the current script to return first

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:59): 13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512: onload will be called some time (probably immediately) after the image is downloaded and decoded and found to not have errors (else it'll call onerror instead, I think), and you can safely use the image for drawing in canvases etc after that
13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512 (22:00): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: so in this phase image is still not read to the memory right?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:01): 13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512: Depends on what you mean by being in memory

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:02): 13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512: Browsers are free to do whatever optimisations they want in terms of caching data in memory, lazy decoding, etc, so you can never really know what they're doing - you just know whether or not it's safe to perform certain actions on images (like drawing them)
13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512 (22:03): I mean, is the image data transferred to a buffer in the memory? or is it simply presented by something like file pointers in C?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:04): Again, you don't know, because browsers are allowed to do what they want.  All you know is that certain actions are allowed at specific points.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:04): It's been downloaded from the network (so you can use it immediately), but everything else is just implementation details that you shouldn't need to know about

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:05): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, the entire IE compatibility list thing can be fairly described as "hard to do", but IE has to do it anyway, since they have to deal with IE-only sites and IE-only code paths, so if they just implemented standards without compatibility they'd break.  (See: IE7.)

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:06): Everyone else tends to get the same code paths in most cases, due to "develop your site for standards-compliant browsers, then fix for IE".  So they can converge on a common behavior without causing more bugs than they prevent, usually.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:06): IE9's goal is explicitly to work with the same exact code everyone else gets, so hopefully IE10 won't need an IE9 compatibility mode.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:08): 13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512: That's an implementation detail :-)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:09): 13a74a99387e388d28a3afb47d1c4512: It seems plausible that some implementations would store all loaded images as decoded RGBA in RAM, so you don't want to load huge amounts of image data and just hope the browser will do something clever with it

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:52): What format do HTML5 tests need to be in?  It occurs to me that I wrote some tests for my Mozilla patch to enable maxlength on textarea, and could probably submit those.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:54): I don't think any format has really been agreed yet
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:54): Well, there must be some way to run all the tests and figure out how many passed, no?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:55): There ought to be
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:56): Actually, there probably shouldn't be a way to run *all* the tests
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:56): because nobody will really want ten thousand results all at once, they'll just focus on a single feature
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:57): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: That's the part that I'm working on.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:58): When there is a standard test format, hopefully all the browsers can write tests for new features using that format and wrap it in their own format for internal use.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:58): That would be cool.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:58): will just submit his own idiosyncratic format for now
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:58): Since it seems to me that WebKit and Gecko must be writing tons of HTML5 tests for internal use, but they aren't submitting them like Microsoft is.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:58): I mean, both of them have an "all new features must have tests" policy . . .
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:59): Yeah, I know our format is very ideosyncratic.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:59): Everyone's is.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:04): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: WebKit definitely has tests for HTML5 features
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:04): I think there would be a few steps required to make them into appropriate tests for a standards test suite:
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:05): 1) ensure that everything tested is associated with specific conformance requirements in the spec
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:05): 2) annotate the tests with the relevant conformance requirements
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:05): 3) convert to whatever format the w3c wants them in
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:05): Come to think of it, my maxlength tests won't work at all cross-browser, because they synthesize keyboard input.  Oops.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:06): we have a lot of tests that are script-driven, and would totally work cross-browser
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:06): we have some that are based on dumps of the render tree structure which would need substantial reworking

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:06): I don't believe Apple, Google, or any of the other big players in WebKit-land have anyone currently tasked with converting WebKit regression tests for test suite use
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (23:08): I think Opera contributes a lot of test, no ?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:10): I believe they do in general, I am not sure how many have been contributed for HTML5 in particular
